node.text: The fast-spreading #deltavariant is raising fresh health concerns even in places where Covid vaccination rates are high. Senior pharmaceuticals analyst Sam Fazeli is here to tell you what you need to know.

node.title: Your Biggest Delta Variant Questions Answered

node.text:
"Donald Trump upended the American presidency after stepping away from the company that made him rich and famous. Four years later, returning to his empire after losing the White House, what he finds may upend him," write Sophie Alexander and Max Abelson.

"Three quarters of Trump's net worth is tied up in urban real estate. And urban real estate has been hammered by Covid-19," Tim O'Brien tells @quicktake's Tim Stenovec.

The former president's net worth is down to $2.3 billion from $3 billion in 2016. The pandemic he promised would disappear is walloping his company, and the riot that got him impeached for a second time is wounding his brand.

Check out "Trump’s Ailing Empire" on bloomberg.com/graphics to see just how deep in peril he really is.

node.text:
👻 Snap Inc. is rolling out a new tool for its Snapchat app to feature popular videos, called Spotlight, and said it will pay out $1 million a day to creators of the top-performing posts. How good of a deal is that?

🤳🏻 "The more remarkable thing about Snap is that it wasn't offering these sort of incentives to people to create good content previously."

Alex Webb joined @quicktake's Tim Steno to explain why Snap decided to compensate viral creators.

#snapchat #influencer #app #creators #snap

node.title: Snapchat to Pay $1 Million a Day to Creators

node.text:
It’s been 20 months since a pair of fatal crashes forced regulators around the globe to ground the once top-selling jet. The FAA finally approved the Max to resume commercial flights today, which will allow Boeing to make money off the roughly 450 Max jets it has built but not yet delivered.

After the longest grounding of an aircraft in modern U.S. history, it’s reasonable to ask whether the plane is safe. Bloomberg Opinion columnists Chris Bryant and Brooke Sutherland teamed up to discuss the future of the Max, and whether or not they'd be willing to board one.

#Boeing #Boeing737 #737max #airplane #aircraft #airline #southwest #americanair #flight #pandemic #livestream #video #igtv #travel

node.title: Boeing’s 737 Max Is Back. Are You Willing to Board?

node.text:
Frank Barry didn’t ask a soul about Donald Trump or Joe Biden on his @looking4lincoln trip. For the two months he spent crossing the country along the Lincoln Highway by Winnebago, talking with Americans and hoping to reach San Francisco by Election Day, he never brought up the campaign. Sometimes he knew how people felt — occasionally they would say, though usually not. But it didn’t matter. He wasn’t running a focus group. He was trying to catch glimpses of a more enduring spirit, the kind that has transcended parties and generations, the kind that lives, as Lincoln said, in the better angels of our nature. And maybe those glimpses could help us see more of ourselves in each other, and in the land we share.

#lincolnhighway #travel #rv #roadtrip #winnebago #highway #ontheroad #interview #video

node.title: The End of the Lincoln Highway

node.text:
“It was really impossible not to feel the immediacy, the urgency of climate change on this leg of the trip.”

Frank Barry stops in #Iowa and #Colorado, continuing his journey across the U.S. along the Lincoln Highway.

Video by @quicktake, footage by @looking4lincoln.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 17, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '"The U.S. economy is on ” of normalcy, not calamity." Matthew Yglesias bag brown medium BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The Covid economy was genuinely scary. And the federal government’s response to it was genuinely admirable: It made the welfare state more robust.

But the pandemic unemployment insurance programs aren’t like a child allowance program or Medicaid, writes Matthew Yglesias — they give you money only if you don’t work, and in many cases they gave people more money than they could earn by working.

Because of the creaky plumbing of the U.S. unemployment insurance system, that was a pragmatic way to deliver help to those in need during a public health crisis. But it’s not a sustainable way to run an economy.

The jobs are out there — and if people need to earn money, they can.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about what the expiration of extra unemployment assistance means for the economy.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'GameStop has big advantages technology startups would die for GameStop shares have soared despite big drops the day after the last four earnings reports GameStop Corp $400 300 200 100 Sep 2020 Jan 2021 Apr Source:Bloomberg Jul BloombergOpinion Bloomberg'.

node.text:
GameStop has several assets most upstarts would die for — including a well-known brand, a loyalty program with about 47 million consumers, executives with a track record of success, and a robust balance sheet of roughly $1.7 billion in net cash.

"I would now frame GameStop as an emerging technology company than a brick-and-mortar retailer. Given the biographies of the revamped management team, it’s clear a big pivot toward e-commerce is underway," writes Tae Kim.

For a company like GameStop that’s undergoing such dramatic change, it pays to take a longer-term view.

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'speed limit on the Autobahn would be great for the planet A 130kph (81mph) Autobahn speed limit saves 1.9 million tons of CO2 yearly CO2 equivalent saving 6M tons of CO2 100kph 120kph Speed limit Source:Umweltbundesamt 130kph Bloomberg Opinion'.

node.text:
🛣️Could Germans’ cherished right to drive as fast as they like on the Autobahn soon be outlawed?

If voted in, the country’s center-left Social Democrats promise to limit motorway speeds to a maximum of 130 km per hour (81 miles per hour).

"I enjoy my Autobahn freedoms as much as the next German, but faced with a worsening climate crisis, high speeds are becoming harder to defend. Motorway speed limits can lower fuel consumption and thereby cut pollution, including planet-heating emissions," writes Chris Bryant.

A 130 kph Autobann speed limit would lower greenhouse gas emissions by 1.9 million tons annually, according to the German Environment Agency. That’s barely 1% of Germany’s overall transport emissions, but nearly 5% of the total produced by cars and light commercial vehicles on highways, it estimates.

Tap the link in our bio to read about more about the benefits of slowing down.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Think used cars are expensive? Take look at totaled cars. While the pace of gains has moderated somewhat, prices of wrecked cars processed through Copart and sold at auction are at record Average Selling Prices, YoY % Increase 60% 40 20 一 Q1 Q2 2018 Q3 Q4 Q1 Q2 2019 Q3 Q4 Source: Q2 2020 Q4 -20 earnings calls, datacome by Bloomberg Q4 Q2 Q3 2021 BloombergOpini'.

node.text:
Copart is a $34 billion company that specializes in auctioning off wrecked cars that insurers deem too damaged to justify the cost of repairs.

There are a few reasons junked-car prices are skyrocketing, writes Brooke Sutherland.

For one thing, “junked” may be a bit of a misnomer in some cases. Traditional buyers of cars processed through Copart have included scrap yards and companies such as LKQ, which dismantles older vehicles and reconditions their parts to be sold in collision-repair shops.

But as vehicles have gotten more sophisticated, with sensors crammed into every possible nook and cranny, even fender benders are increasingly expensive to fix. This gives insurers a greater economic incentive to declare a banged-up vehicle totaled and sell it through Copart rather than try to repair it.

But that also means a growing number of junked vehicles are relatively new and can be made workable again.

“If you visited some of our yards, you would be astonished by some of the high-value Range Rovers and European vehicles that you would see on the lots that at least on their surface look perfectly good and perfectly functional — and in many cases are,” President Jeff Liaw said on a call Thursday to discuss Copart’s results.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the economic opportunity behind wrecked cars.

Note: Beginning in Q4 2020, Copart began reporting a global average selling price. It had previously only disclosed data for the U.S. Data for Q2 2019 and Q2 2018 excluded the impact of Hurricane Harvey for apples-to-apples comparison.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 16, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says '18-year-old Emma Raducanu isararityeven is a rarity in elite sport- a unicorn BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Emma Raducanu’s victory at the U.S. Open last Saturday turned the Toronto-born Brit into one of those athletes who transcends their sport — who you can’t help but watch and want to know more, or even pick up a racquet.

"Raducanu a rarity even in elite sport — a unicorn," writes Therese Raphael.

These figures are different not just because they dominate their sport, but because they alter the landscape around them. But as unicorns in the tech world know, that’s no easy ride. Potential that huge, growth that fast and adulation that fervent can be tricky to sustain and manage.

“In 35 years in the industry, I would have to go back to the days of Tiger Woods to think of something similar,” says Michel Masquelier, former chairman of IMG Media.

The inevitable questions have already begun. How long will it take her to top the world rankings? Where will she play next? Which sponsorship deals will she agree to?

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the latest athlete to reach unicorn status.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'If your employer made you get vaccinated, would youqui If your employer required you to get vaccinated before coming in to work, what would you be most likely to do? 60% 40 20 Get Vaccinated Ask for exemption Source: Washington Post-ABC News poll, Aug. 29-Sept. Note:Participants' currently Quit No opinion BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
In a recent poll, an astounding 42% of respondents (all of whom were unvaccinated and with employers that, at the time, did not require proof of vaccination) said they were willing to quit their job if their employer made them get the vaccine.

In Allison Schrager’s latest column, she writes that good policies can be bad economics: “Workers have never had more power in the labor market: If someone quits rather than get a vaccine or needs to be fired, it will be very expensive and difficult to replace them.”

Although this sort of pushback is to be expected, Bloomberg’s editorial board writes that “Biden’s opponents ought to stop and think. His initiative should unite the country in a new determination to defeat its common enemy.”

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how far the unvaccinated are willing to go.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion in Cupertino, California. May be an image of phone and text that says 'Apple's new iPhones may be the weakest upgrade ever BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
What is this world coming to? Yesterday was an Apple Event day. Did you even realize that?

Once this would have been a time of national celebration. Children would have been opening iAdvent calendars and leaving milk and cookies out for Jony Ive. Instead, now we’re all “Met Gala this” and “Nicki Minaj said what about vaccines? that.”

Our national fabric is unraveling before our eyes. That, or maybe it’s just that the new Apple phones are … boring? Not really necessary?

Normally, for the more than 1 billion iPhone enthusiasts around the world, no product unveiling is more anticipated than Apple’s annual reveal of its newest lineup of smartphones. Except for maybe this time.

The iPhone 13 line introduces “minor enhancements,” mainly just making old stuff incrementally faster, bigger and nicer. For those of us still toting around iPhone 4s, it may be time to upgrade. But most of us are hanging onto our old devices longer and longer, writes Tae Kim.

Tap the link in our bio to read Kim's column in full.

#apple #appleevent #iphone13

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'China Chinais projected toreach high-income status before 2025 Brazil Russia India World Bank middle-income upper bound (2021) 20K 15 10 5 2000 2010 Soure:Bloomberg/IMF Bloomberg/IM 2020 2026 Bloomberg Opinion'.

node.text:
China is already on the cusp of gaining high-income status. Based on the World Bank’s current threshold and International Monetary Fund forecasts, the country should achieve that goal before 2025.

Gaining admission to the rich-nations club doesn’t denote lifetime membership, though. It’s possible for countries to go into reverse and drop back into the middle-income category — just look at Russia.

"The likelihood is that in resisting reforms other economies have found necessary to compete at higher income levels, Xi will condemn China to a future of subpar growth," Matthew Brooker writes.

Tap the link in our bio to read about how Xi may end up inadvertently undermining the foundations of the the Communist Party's legitimacy.

#xi #china #chart

node.text:
Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is making a bold statement just as President Biden’s push to raise taxes on the wealthy is getting undermined by centrists.

The tax committee in the House of Representatives released some long-awaited details Monday of how Democrats plan to raise taxes on top earners to help pay for social programs. It’s an effort to split some of the wide differences between the soak-the-rich tendencies of the party’s activist progressives and the be-careful-what-you-wish-for centrists.

"That’s a tough balance to strike, and the strain shows, especially in two messy compromises that would create more problems than they solve," writes Alexis Leondis.

The plan fails to close a long-standing loophole in the tax code, which will sabotage a key tax increase Democrats were relying on to deliver enough revenue to finance their programs.

Under the current system, most investors aren't taxed on any appreciation in their portfolios when they die. In other words, in the eyes of the Internal Revenue Service, dying isn't a taxable event (unless your estate is worth more than $11.7 million).

Tap the link in our bio to read more about where the tax plan falls short of AOC's desire to soak the rich.

#aoc #metgala #taxtherich

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 14, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'electricity prices are up 560% compared with a year ago U.K. electricity prices reached £277 per megawatt hour on Sept. 8 N2EX Power Exchange U.K. Day-Ahead Power Auction Baseload Index £300MWh 200 100 Oct 2020 Jan 2021 Apr Source:Bloomberg Jul BloombergO'.

node.text:
🇬🇧A perfect storm is brewing in the U.K. energy landscape.

The price of gas, carbon and coal — the fossil fuels components that set prices — have all risen sharply. Wind output has dropped, while Russian gas flowing into Europe has been lower than expected. Weather extremes have meant higher demand for both heating and cooling in Asia and Europe. There have been outages in nuclear and other facilities. The U.K. had also reduced its gas storage capacity, making it more vulnerable. Prices have risen all over Europe, too.

Even Brexit costs factor in here as the trading of energy through interconnectors — the physical network connecting Britain to the Continent — is more costly to manage. Carbon prices rose by almost 50% between the April and September, while gas prices have risen by almost 200% in that time.

"Especially if it’s a cold winter, prices are only going to rise further, and there are concerns about supply too," writes Therese Raphael.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about why Britain's energy crisis is about to get worse.

#uk #britain #energy #climate

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on September 13, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Covidis on its way to becoming just another virus BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🦠 We're not there yet, but it's time to start thinking about Covid as endemic.

In Singapore, the Ministry of Health has started prioritizing data on hospitalizations rather than infections. Israel is riding out a surge in new Covid cases without returning to lockdowns for the vaccinated.

It’s hard to believe that an infection that’s killed more than 4.5 million people could be thought of in such a routine way. But viruses throughout history have flipped between endemic and pandemic status with remarkable frequency. 

The moment we’ve beaten Covid won’t be when we eradicate it from the human population. It will be when we’ve reached a level of vaccinated and natural immunity where we no longer have reason to fear it, writes David Fickling.

May be an image of text that says 'Unvaccinated people inL.A. were 29 times more likely to be hospitalized Age-adjusted rolling seven-day Covid hospitalizations per 100,000 people Unvaccinated Fully vaccinated 30 20 10 May 1 2021 May 15 Jun1 Jun 15 Jul1 Angeles County Jul15 Jul25 BloombergOpinior Bloom'.

node.text:
“My message to unvaccinated Americans is this: What more is there to wait for? What more do you need to see?”

President Biden makes a good point: The merits of vaccination are not nearly as complicated as the John Mulaney-Olivia Munn pregnancy timeline.

Although Biden’s question is more of a rhetorical one, this chart just might help simplify matters even more. A recent study done in Los Angeles County found that unvaccinated people were 29 times more likely than vaccinated people to end up in the hospital with Covid-19 infections.

In Cathy O’Neil’s latest column, she writes that “vaccines are still effective, miraculously so. Getting inoculated can save your life, and certainly justifies living more like normal.”

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the value of vaccination.
